# Philosophy of mind

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Phrenology1.jpg/200px-
Phrenology1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Phrenology1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Phrenology1.jpg "Enlarge")

A phrenological [mapping](/wiki/Brain_mapping "Brain mapping")[1] of the
[brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain") – [phrenology](/wiki/Phrenology "Phrenology") was
among the first attempts to correlate mental functions with specific parts of
the brain although it is now largely discredited.

**Philosophy of mind** is a branch of [philosophy](/wiki/Philosophy
"Philosophy") that studies the nature of the [mind](/wiki/Mind "Mind"). The
[mind–body problem](/wiki/Mind%E2%80%93body_problem "Mind–body problem") is a
paradigm issue in philosophy of mind, although other issues are addressed,
such as the [hard problem of
consciousness](/wiki/Hard_problem_of_consciousness "Hard problem of
consciousness"), and the nature of particular mental states.[2][3][4] Aspects
of the mind that are studied include [mental events](/wiki/Mental_event
"Mental event"), [mental functions](/wiki/Mental_function "Mental function"),
[mental properties](/wiki/Mental_property "Mental property"),
[consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness "Consciousness"), the ontology of the
mind, the nature of thought, and the relationship of the mind to the body.

[Dualism](/wiki/Dualism_\(philosophy_of_mind\) "Dualism \(philosophy of
mind\)") and [monism](/wiki/Monism "Monism") are the two central [schools of
thought](/wiki/Schools_of_thought "Schools of thought") on the mind–body
problem, although nuanced views have arisen that do not fit one or the other
category neatly. Dualism is seen even in the Eastern tradition, in the
[Sankhya](/wiki/Sankhya "Sankhya") and [Yoga](/wiki/Yoga "Yoga") schools of
[Hindu](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") philosophy,[5] and [Plato](/wiki/Plato
"Plato"),[6] but its entry into Western philosophy was thanks to [René
Descartes](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes "René Descartes") in the 17th century.[7]
Substance dualists like Descartes argue that the mind is an independently
existing [substance](/wiki/Substance_\(philosophy\) "Substance
\(philosophy\)"), whereas [property dualists](/wiki/Property_dualism "Property
dualism") maintain that the mind is a group of independent properties that
[emerge](/wiki/Emergentism "Emergentism") from and cannot be reduced to the
brain, but that it is not a distinct substance.[8]

Monism is the position that mind and body are not
[ontologically](/wiki/Ontology "Ontology") distinct entities (independent
substances). This view was first advocated in [Western
philosophy](/wiki/Western_philosophy "Western philosophy") by
[Parmenides](/wiki/Parmenides "Parmenides") in the 5th century BC and was
later espoused by the 17th century [rationalist](/wiki/Rationalism
"Rationalism") [Baruch Spinoza](/wiki/Baruch_Spinoza "Baruch Spinoza").[9]
[Physicalists](/wiki/Physicalism "Physicalism") argue that only entities
postulated by physical theory exist, and that mental processes will eventually
be explained in terms of these entities as physical theory continues to
evolve. Physicalists maintain various positions on the prospects of reducing
mental properties to physical properties (many of whom adopt compatible forms
of property dualism),[10][11][12][13][14][15] and the ontological status of
such mental properties remains unclear.[14][16][17]
[Idealists](/wiki/Idealism_\(philosophy\) "Idealism \(philosophy\)") maintain
that the mind is all that exists and that the external world is either mental
itself, or an illusion created by the mind. [Neutral
monists](/wiki/Neutral_monism "Neutral monism") such as [Ernst
Mach](/wiki/Ernst_Mach "Ernst Mach") and [William James](/wiki/William_James
"William James") argue that events in the world can be thought of as either
mental (psychological) or physical depending on the network of relationships
into which they enter, and dual-aspect monists such as
[Spinoza](/wiki/Baruch_Spinoza "Baruch Spinoza") adhere to the position that
there is some other, neutral substance, and that both matter and mind are
properties of this unknown substance. The most common monisms in the 20th and
21st centuries have all been variations of physicalism; these positions
include [behaviorism](/wiki/Behaviorism "Behaviorism"), the [type identity
theory](/wiki/Type_physicalism "Type physicalism"), [anomalous
monism](/wiki/Anomalous_monism "Anomalous monism") and
[functionalism](/wiki/Functionalism_\(philosophy_of_mind\) "Functionalism
\(philosophy of mind\)").[18]

Most modern philosophers of mind adopt either a reductive or non-reductive
physicalist position, maintaining in their different ways that the mind is not
something separate from the body.[18] These approaches have been particularly
influential in the sciences, especially in the fields of
[sociobiology](/wiki/Sociobiology "Sociobiology"), [computer
science](/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science"), [evolutionary
psychology](/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology "Evolutionary psychology") and the
various [neurosciences](/wiki/Neuroscience "Neuroscience").[19][20][21][22]
Reductive physicalists assert that all mental states and properties will
eventually be explained by scientific accounts of physiological processes and
states.[23][24][25] Non-reductive physicalists argue that although the mind is
not a separate substance, mental properties [supervene](/wiki/Supervenience
"Supervenience") on physical properties, or that the predicates and vocabulary
used in mental descriptions and explanations are indispensable, and cannot be
reduced to the language and lower-level explanations of physical
science.[26][27] Continued [neuroscientific](/wiki/Neuroscientific
"Neuroscientific") progress has helped to clarify some of these issues;
however, they are far from being resolved. Modern philosophers of mind
continue to ask how the subjective qualities and the
[intentionality](/wiki/Intentionality "Intentionality") of mental states and
properties can be explained in naturalistic terms.[28][29]
